body: The pattern match (which tries to match directories directly) in the `hashFiles()` function is incorrect, see https://github.com/actions/toolkit/blob/bb2278e5cfbb40afc20890c415e9ffa836631cd5/packages/glob/src/internal-hash-files.ts#L28

comment_regular_data.body: Nit: type should be `ci`, not  `fix` (distinction is important for release note generation).
I don't really understand the problem. I quickly checked the linked code but I don't know TS that well. Does the caching not work currently?

This looks right to me. ~~node projects tend to use https://github.com/isaacs/node-glob which~~ (edit: this GHA isn't using that though) wants `/**/` to recurse. Whereas `cmake**` won't do what we expect, I think.

> Nit: type should be `ci`, not `fix` (distinction is important for release note generation).

Corrected it and added it as a commit lint rule.

> this GHA isn't using that though

It should use [`@actions/glob`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@actions/glob#patterns).

> I don't really understand the problem. I quickly checked the linked code but I don't know TS that well. Does the caching not work currently?

I noticed that there might be this issue when @clason tried to bump libuv version at https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30861#issuecomment-2423749315, where the version of libuv was changed, but my PR (including subsequent PRs from others during that time) has the same error as https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30861.

You could be right, but I think you're assuming too much. The only way to know for sure it doesn't work is to check whether the hash number doesn't change when a relevant file changes. I can check later to make sure.

Regardless, perhaps this is more readable even if it turns out the current syntax works?

> but I think you're assuming too much.

I indeed do not have much experience with CI and caching.

> Regardless, perhaps this is more readable even if it turns out the current syntax works?

I have considered this, and even though `cmake**` and `.github/**` are valid (i.e., providing a folder equals hashing all its contents), [this usage is not mentioned in the documentation for `hashFiles`,](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/writing-workflows/choosing-what-your-workflow-does/evaluate-expressions-in-workflows-and-actions#hashfiles) which specifies examples down to the file level. At the very least, this PR should be safe.

> I have considered this, and even though cmake** and .github/** are valid

It is? I interpreted the commit/PR message/code link to mean it wasn't. In that case this is more about readability or not relying on undocumented features?
Even if they're valid, they might behave differently.

My point is that regardless of whether `cmake**` and `.github/**` are valid, we should not rely on this usage as long as it is not documented. And I do *assume* they are invalid (by reading the source code, not by practice).

I confirmed caching works currently, whatever failure you saw was unrelated to that.

> And I do assume they are invalid (by reading the source code, not by practice).

lmao, next time I suggest you just test it out instead of assuming things.

Anyway, I don't see any harm in this and the new glob syntax is probably easier to read, so let's go with that.

Sorry to trouble you with confirmation, and thank you for your suggestion. Next time, I will test it out myself. I rushed to create this PR directly because I didn't see such syntax in the documentation.
Forgot about this, is it not needed ?
